article.title: Global Memory Shortage Crisis: Market Analysis

summary: A severe global memory chip shortage driven by surging AI data center demand is disrupting smartphone and PC markets, with effects expected through 2027. Memory manufacturers are reallocating production capacity toward high-margin AI-specific components, causing supply constraints and price inflation for consumer devices.
keyPoints: Memory shortage intensifies from late 2025, driven by AI infrastructure growth demanding high-bandwidth and high-capacity DRAM.
Major suppliers (Samsung, SK Hynix, Micron) prioritize AI server memory over consumer DRAM and NAND, shrinking supply for smartphones and PCs.
Smartphone market could contract 2.9%-5.2% in 2026; ASPs may rise 3%-8%, disproportionately impacting low-margin vendors like TCL and Xiaomi.
PC market faces a potential 4.9%-8.9% decline in 2026, with larger OEMs positioned to gain share from smaller assemblers amid supply constraints.
AI PC growth is threatened as rising memory costs and shortages limit RAM upgrades, despite increasing demand for 16GB+ configurations.
The shortage represents a structural shift in silicon wafer allocation, signaling a medium-term end to cheap, abundant memory.

rewrite.title: Global Memory Shortage Reshapes Tech Markets
rewrite.body:
Starting in late 2025, the global semiconductor industry is confronting an unprecedented memory chip shortage, primarily fueled by explosive demand from AI data centers. This surge in AI workloads requires specialized high-bandwidth memory (HBM) and large-capacity DDR5 modules, prompting leading manufacturers—Samsung Electronics, SK Hynix, and Micron—to divert production away from conventional DRAM and NAND used in consumer devices. The resulting supply squeeze has driven memory prices sharply higher, disrupting the smartphone and PC markets.

In smartphones, memory costs constitute 10-20% of the bill of materials, making the shortage particularly impactful. Low-margin manufacturers such as TCL, Transsion, and Xiaomi face significant margin pressure and are likely to pass increased costs to consumers. IDC forecasts a 2.9% to 5.2% contraction in global smartphone shipments in 2026, alongside average selling price increases of 3% to 8%, with the largest price hikes expected in budget segments. Premium brands like Apple and Samsung are somewhat insulated due to long-term supply contracts but may still limit RAM upgrades and slow typical price erosion on new models.

The PC market is similarly affected, with IDC projecting a 4.9% to 8.9% decline in 2026 shipments under moderate to pessimistic scenarios. Larger OEMs with stronger supply chain leverage are poised to capture market share from smaller and regional players, including white-box assemblers and gaming system builders. This shift coincides with a critical juncture for AI-enabled PCs, which require higher RAM capacities (16GB minimum for some models). Rising memory costs threaten to stall this segment’s growth by forcing compromises on pricing or specifications.

Overall, the shortage marks a strategic reallocation of silicon wafer capacity toward high-margin AI memory products, fundamentally altering the semiconductor landscape. This structural change signals an end to the era of inexpensive, plentiful memory and storage, with 2026 expected to bring sustained higher costs and slower volume growth across consumer and enterprise technology sectors.
